class=\"widget widget-ArticleTopInfo widget-instance-OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget article-top-widget\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n        <div class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    VDES J2325\u22125229 a <em>z</em> = 2.7 gravitationally lensed quasar discovered using morphology-independent supervised machine learning\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                            <div class=\"meta-authors--limited\">\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-name js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                        <a class=\"linked-name\" href=\"javascript:;\">Fernanda Ostrovski</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    Fernanda Ostrovski\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-cor1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"cor1\" data-open=\"cor1\" class=\"link () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>        </div>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Eccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nEccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f465%2f4%2f4325%2f2544365\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58436929 id=\"58436929\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the discovery and preliminary characterization of a gravitationally lensed quasar with a source redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2.74 and image separation of 2.9 arcsec lensed by a foreground <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.40 elliptical galaxy. Since optical observations of gravitationally lensed quasars show the lens system as a superposition of multiple point sources and a foreground lensing galaxy, we have developed a morphology-independent multi-wavelength approach to the photometric selection of lensed quasar candidates based on Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) supervised machine learning. Using this technique and <em>gi</em> multicolour photometric observations from the Dark Energy Survey (DES), near-IR <em>JK</em> photometry from the VISTA Hemisphere Survey (VHS) and WISE mid-IR photometry, we have identified a candidate system with two catalogue components with <em>i<sub>AB</sub></em> = 18.61 and <em>i<sub>AB</sub></em> = 20.44 comprising an elliptical galaxy and two blue point sources. Spectroscopic follow-up with NTT and the use of an archival AAT spectrum show that the point sources can be identified as a lensed quasar with an emission line redshift of <em>z</em> = 2.739 \u00b1 0.003 and a foreground early-type galaxy with <em>z</em> = 0.400 \u00b1 0.002. We model the system as a single isothermal ellipsoid and find the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub> \u223c 1.47 arcsec, enclosed mass <em>M</em><sub>enc</sub> \u223c 4 \u00d7 10<sup>11</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> and a time delay of \u223c52\u00a0d. The relatively wide separation, month scale time delay duration and high redshift make this an ideal system for constraining the expansion rate beyond a redshift of 1.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: observational&quot;\">methods: observational</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: general&quot;\">quasars: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58436931 id=\"58436931\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery of the first strong gravitational lens (Walsh, Carswell &amp; Weymann\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>) brought forth a powerful tool to study cosmology and astrophysics. Systems where the background source is a quasar can be used to map the dark matter substructure (e.g. Mao &amp; Schneider\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Kochanek &amp; Dalal\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), to determine the mass (e.g. Morgan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and spin (Reynolds et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) of black holes, to measure the properties of distant host galaxies (e.g. Kochanek, Keeton &amp; McLeod\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Claeskens et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Peng et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and to measure the value of the Hubble constant <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. The constraints on cosmological parameters in particular are comparable in precision to baryonic acoustic oscillation methods (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In addition to that, the effects of microlensing of the quasar induced by the stars in the lens galaxy can be used to probe the physical properties of quasar accretion discs such as the wavelength dependence of the size of the accretion disc (e.g. Poindexter, Morgan &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Large samples of new quasar lens systems were discovered through dedicated surveys in radio, like the Cosmic Lens All Sky Survey (CLASS; Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Browne et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), which, in combination with the Jodrell Bank VLA Astrometric Survey (JVAS; King et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), found 21 new lens systems, and in the optical, such as the SDSS (Sloan Digital Sky Survey) Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Inada et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which discovered 49 new lensed systems.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> The future of the field is currently hindered by the need for more lenses. This can be achieved, according to Oguri &amp; Marshall\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a> (hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>), not by increasing the depth of the searches, but the area. Therefore, surveys such as the Dark Energy Survey (DES; DES Collaboration\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; DES Collaboration et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and, in the future, the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST; Ivezic et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) are capable of more than doubling the current quasar lens sample size.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The chance of a given quasar being lensed was determined by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> to be \u223c10<sup>\u22123.5</sup>, which is comparable to what was obtained with SQLS. (It shows a rate of quasar lensing of \u223c10<sup>\u22123.3</sup>.) In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> we show the expected number of lenses in the full DES survey area as a function of <em>i</em>-band magnitude according to the predictions by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>. We show the expected numbers for pairs and quads (lenses with four quasar images) according to the magnitude of the brightest image in the system (<em>i</em><sub>1</sub>). For comparison, we also plotted the expected number of lenses according to the magnitude of the fainter image (for pairs) or the third brightest image (for quads), <em>i</em><sub>2/3</sub>, which is the limit used by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58436935\" scrollto-destination=\"58436935\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=N5Z4uscIteJ3ZolkUaRgX8A6lDCP6kzWV836BARoKmsxHnWs-FWZpECXcisSp-U76yT7AfGTM3ZKT-9Z5ycEYkyY-VXXj6m2lwRLBytfhf-rsQSSDJ2KlDNbUxQSTxXXumQOIEiq384Q1AIqer8vnGWbyIRrdvr8fFIKmWVv80DWCTZu9iQIZB2oy-WNcB0U7oxLrBrY6lWLICZF0trWKpv5KEZSlX~wRfaFddjKuV1vDb3eo2cvZ3WERRcTd-1y7rAF9vNJFue-Ypj6NBhUC2nbl5u4RZ4KN6Vbghg8jSlT-d~ElHqyOG0kho~ud2G7UcsrF3MxiLDD8QAHzBvgDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Expected number of quasar lenses in the full DES area as a function of the magnitude of the brightest quasar image. The blue solid line shows the overall expected number of systems, while the dashed pink line and the dotted green line show the number of pairs and quads, respectively. The dot\u2013dashed black line shows the expected number of lenses as a function of the magnitude of the second brightest quasar image for pairs and third brightest image for quads.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436935/stw2958fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436935\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=Sdn2hefKDzoJjxbV1aaApHbNHvYQLNlcZEPx7Am4xCp3lduItwxGYKNHsX9uZwTYqIiZHKbjVIjuIKKgwdocq~GkqNXf0eIIAcQn38f~JtAN2MrDRWFeW4O-adKu897siRyt-cUDUd4PedjgqYiVE530o7JpPqYX5E1dCCHYE4JvOmcDTlPl6Pjv39LtGad0Ev9nlphgXqnnbkBRfu~20HHNRVi7QbCsOghlzsLEXg5hblZYAcOo-lva7InzQp~ETyXRIjBT-SawaQEyE9e~28VoTsSvNKg2Sa~rzlKfs3RNezGDR1pelJ1Kxu85~v65tUfwtpFfYdTii~oQf6Wd4w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436935&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Expected number of quasar lenses in the full DES area as a function of the magnitude of the brightest quasar image. The blue solid line shows the overall expected number of systems, while the dashed pink line and the dotted green line show the number of pairs and quads, respectively. The dot\u2013dashed black line shows the expected number of lenses as a function of the magnitude of the second brightest quasar image for pairs and third brightest image for quads.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=N5Z4uscIteJ3ZolkUaRgX8A6lDCP6kzWV836BARoKmsxHnWs-FWZpECXcisSp-U76yT7AfGTM3ZKT-9Z5ycEYkyY-VXXj6m2lwRLBytfhf-rsQSSDJ2KlDNbUxQSTxXXumQOIEiq384Q1AIqer8vnGWbyIRrdvr8fFIKmWVv80DWCTZu9iQIZB2oy-WNcB0U7oxLrBrY6lWLICZF0trWKpv5KEZSlX~wRfaFddjKuV1vDb3eo2cvZ3WERRcTd-1y7rAF9vNJFue-Ypj6NBhUC2nbl5u4RZ4KN6Vbghg8jSlT-d~ElHqyOG0kho~ud2G7UcsrF3MxiLDD8QAHzBvgDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Expected number of quasar lenses in the full DES area as a function of the magnitude of the brightest quasar image. The blue solid line shows the overall expected number of systems, while the dashed pink line and the dotted green line show the number of pairs and quads, respectively. The dot\u2013dashed black line shows the expected number of lenses as a function of the magnitude of the second brightest quasar image for pairs and third brightest image for quads.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436935/stw2958fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436935\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=Sdn2hefKDzoJjxbV1aaApHbNHvYQLNlcZEPx7Am4xCp3lduItwxGYKNHsX9uZwTYqIiZHKbjVIjuIKKgwdocq~GkqNXf0eIIAcQn38f~JtAN2MrDRWFeW4O-adKu897siRyt-cUDUd4PedjgqYiVE530o7JpPqYX5E1dCCHYE4JvOmcDTlPl6Pjv39LtGad0Ev9nlphgXqnnbkBRfu~20HHNRVi7QbCsOghlzsLEXg5hblZYAcOo-lva7InzQp~ETyXRIjBT-SawaQEyE9e~28VoTsSvNKg2Sa~rzlKfs3RNezGDR1pelJ1Kxu85~v65tUfwtpFfYdTii~oQf6Wd4w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436935&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Expected number of quasar lenses in the full DES area as a function of the magnitude of the brightest quasar image. The blue solid line shows the overall expected number of systems, while the dashed pink line and the dotted green line show the number of pairs and quads, respectively. The dot\u2013dashed black line shows the expected number of lenses as a function of the magnitude of the second brightest quasar image for pairs and third brightest image for quads.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">With 50 lensed quasar systems with <em>i</em><sub>1</sub> &lt; 19.0 expected in DES, the challenge becomes how to identify them. SQLS started from a spectroscopic sample of quasars. However, the relatively low numbers of confirmed quasars in the Southern hemisphere sky, and the fact that a large spectroscopic survey is not planned for the next few years, requires a method to photometrically select quasars to look for lenses. Traditionally, that selection would rely on the use of the <em>u</em> band to look for UVX objects (e.g. Croom et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Richards et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). The lack of this band in DES requires the use of the near- and mid-IR to make the selection. The use of mid-IR has been applied efficiently for flux-limited quasar selection (e.g. Stern et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Assef et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and DiPompeo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) have shown that the use of SDSS+WISE photometry provided results similar to those obtained with SDSS+UV+near-IR data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we present results of a search for gravitationally lensed quasars from DES Year 1 observations (Diehl et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), obtained between 2013 August 31 and 2014 February 10, combined with <em>JK</em> near infrared observations from the VISTA Hemisphere Survey (VHS; McMahon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; ESO Observing Programme 179.A-2010) and Wide Infra-red Survey Explorer (WISE; Wright et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). All magnitudes are quoted on the AB system. The conversions from Vega to AB that have been used for the VISTA data are: <em>J<sub>AB</sub></em> = <em>J</em><sub>Vega</sub> + 0.937 and <em>Ks<sub>AB</sub></em> = <em>Ks</em><sub>Vega</sub> + 1.839. These are taken from the Cambridge Astronomical Survey Unit's website.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> The conversions for the ALLWISE data are <em>W</em>1<sub><em>AB</em></sub> = <em>W</em>1<sub>Vega</sub> + 2.699 and <em>W</em>2<sub><em>AB</em></sub> = <em>W</em>2<sub>Vega</sub> + 3.339 which are given in Jarrett et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and in the <em>ALLWISE</em> explanatory supplement.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> When required, a flat cosmology with \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70.0\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> was used unless otherwise specified.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58436938 id=\"58436938\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 CANDIDATE SELECTION AND MODELLING</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58436939 id=\"58436939\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Photometric data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our selection strategy is based on the identification of objects with quasar-like colours that either appear as close pairs or exhibit shape parameters that differ from single point sources. While the motivation for the first criterion is obvious: lensed quasars will appear as multiple images in the sky; the reasoning for the second criterion arises from the fact that, with a median seeing varying between 0.87 and 1.17 arcsec across bands, only wider separation lensed quasars in DES will appear as deblended sources. This becomes an even greater problem if the lensing galaxy is bright enough to contaminate the quasar images, posing a complex problem for source segmentation. Even if the individual components of a lensed quasar system are deblended, the pixel assignment to each segmented source is uncertain and the measured catalogue parameters for each quasar image might not manifest as a canonical point source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">One can define morphology as the difference between <em>psf</em> and <em>model</em> magnitudes in one or more bands: mag<sub>psf</sub> \u2212 mag<sub>model</sub>. Effectively, this is the difference between the best-fitted local point spread function and the radial light profile of a galaxy. When compared to mag<sub>psf</sub>, the value of mag<sub>model</sub> for extended objects will show an excess since their light profiles will extend beyond what is enclosed by the PSF modelling. However, pixel assignment may wrongly distribute flux from companion sources and hence lead to an overestimation of mag<sub>model</sub> and subsequently cause two adjacent point sources to appear non-stellar in the catalogue. Tests performed with lenses simulated according to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> mock catalogue of lensed quasars confirm this result. With 4400 lenses with separations varying between 0.5 and 4.0 arcsec and with <em>i</em> &lt; 21.5 for the input magnitudes for the source quasar, we find that no system with image separation less than 1.5 arcsec is segmented and only 23\u2009per\u2009cent of pairs are deblended into separate sources. Out of those, only 32\u2009per\u2009cent are deblended into point sources. For wider separation lenses, where more massive lensing galaxies can be expected, the contamination by the lensing galaxy on the <em>model</em> magnitude of the quasar images is evident, with only 9\u2009per\u2009cent of the systems where <em>i</em><sub>lens</sub> &lt; 20.0 deblending into point source quasar images. When one looks at systems where <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> &lt; 1.0, where the lens galaxy makes a bigger contribution, only 25\u2009per\u2009cent of the lenses show point source quasar images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This calls for a search for objects with quasar colours regardless of image morphology. Ideally, such a technique would also include objects where lensing galaxy flux is present but this is beyond the scope of this paper and will be presented elsewhere (Ostrovski et\u00a0al., in preparation). Previous quasar selection work such as was done by SDSS focused on selection of point sources prior to the colour selection criterion. Extended sources were selected only if they showed colours that were very different from those of quiescent galaxies (Richards et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Thus lensed quasar surveys such as SQLS will be biased against unresolved candidates. Difference imaging, as suggested by Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), could also be used with DES multi-epoch observations to identify lensed quasars in those cases where a lensed quasar component exhibits variability.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In our selection we use DES Y1 data from the first annual release (Y1A1) co-added catalogue, which cover an area of approximately 1800\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in the Southern hemisphere sky (Bechtol et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). DES images are obtained using the Dark Energy Camera (Flaugher et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and reduced through the DES Data Management system (Mohr et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) using the source extraction code <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). Candidates are selected from an input sample composed of the set of all objects brighter than <em>i</em><sub>auto</sub> &lt; 19.0 in the DES Y1 co-added catalogue which have valid photometry in the <em>g</em> band and are a match to WISE within a 2 arcsec search radius. Objects are also matched to VHS, which includes \u223c1700\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of overlap area with DES, to obtain photometry in <em>J</em> and <em>K</em> using a 1.44 arcsec search radius. Given the bright limit in our sample, the selection will be performed on a high signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) regime and as such it should lead to good performance. The final <em>giJKW</em>1<em>W</em>2 photometric sample on which the gravitationally lensed quasar selection will be performed contains \u223c4.2 \u00d7 10<sup>6</sup> objects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The quasar-like colour similarity is calculated in a five-dimensional colour space composed of <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i, i</em> \u2212 <em>W</em>1, <em>J</em> \u2212 <em>K, K</em> \u2212 <em>W</em>1 and <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2. For the DES bands we use <em>auto</em> magnitudes. The <em>auto</em> magnitudes are intended as an estimate of the total flux given by a Kron-like (Kron\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) automatic aperture. While <em>psf</em> magnitudes are optimized to measure the fluxes of stars and <em>model</em> magnitudes are well suited for galaxies, blended quasar lenses wound not be well represented by either model. By using a magnitude defined by an elliptical aperture based on the second-order moments of the object's light distribution, at least 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the flux should be included and we hope to get well-represented colours independent of object shape. For lensed systems in particular, we want to avoid losing light from one of the components, i.e. having a <em>psf</em> magnitude centred on the lensing galaxy only, and a subsequent misclassification. For the VHS bands we use aperture magnitudes (with an aperture radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r=\\sqrt{2}$|</span> arcsec), analogous to the DES <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span><em>auto</em> magnitudes. For the lower resolution (FWHM = 6 arcsec) WISE bands we use the profile-fitting photometry made available in the catalogues. Given the low resolution of the survey, all objects regardless of morphology appear as point sources.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58436945 id=\"58436945\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Supervised machine learning</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply supervised machine learning to select the candidates. In this work, we use Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) implemented using astroML (Vanderplas et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and scikit-learn (Pedregosa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) tools and trained on objects from the Stripe-82 area (S82), a 2<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{.}^{\\circ}$|</span>5 wide stripe along the Celestial Equator in the Southern Galactic Cap imaged multiple times by SDSS (Abazajian et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and other surveys of varying wavelengths. In DES Y1, S82 covers an area of \u223c167\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. The S82 sample was selected in a similar way to our input sample, but we required all five DES bands to have valid photometry. The resulting sample contains 258\u00a0267 objects, 836 of which are spectroscopically confirmed type 1 quasars from the training set used by Richards et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) in their classifier. Given the <em>i</em> &lt; 19.0 mag limit we are using and the multi-survey spectroscopic follow-up in S82, we believe we have a complete type 1 quasar sample to train on. Objects in the training set are separated into two classes, quasars and non-quasars, and the GMM method models each class as a set of 10 Gaussians.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Tests to evaluate the method's performance with different combinations of colours were conducted by separating 25\u2009per\u2009cent of this training set into a testing sample. Results show that \u223c88.8\u2009per\u2009cent of the quasars are recovered and the rate of false positives, that is sources that are classified as quasars but are not quasars, is \u223c27.0\u2009per\u2009cent. The classes are assigned based on the highest probability and no minimal thresholds were required. A paper detailing this method is under preparation (Ostrovski et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The GMM returns 19\u00a0651 quasar candidates from the input sample, out of which 70 are pairs within 10 arcsec of each other. As expected, most of those objects (\u223c61\u00a0per\u00a0cent) are point sources. We consider an object to be stellar-like if <em>i</em><sub>psf</sub> \u2212 <em>i</em><sub>model</sub> &lt; 0.1, a more conservative approach than what was done in the SDSS photometric survey (Stoughton et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). By removing point sources from our candidate list, we reduce it to 7634 objects. A quick visual inspection of some of the candidates shows that low-redshift galaxies are the most obvious contaminants. This group includes starburst galaxies and <em>z</em> &lt; 0.8 quasars, where, given DES depth, surface brightness limit and resolution, the host galaxy of the AGN becomes prominent. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> summarizes the cleaning and selection steps applied to the original DES Y1 sample down to the final visual inspection sample containing 4478 objects that led to the discovery of J2325\u22125229. We list the different criteria applied and the remaining number of objects after each step.</p>                        <a id=\"58436949\" scrollto-destination=\"58436949\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate selection.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Criterion<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Objects remaining<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>DES Y1: <em>i</em><sub>auto</sub> &lt; 19.0\u00a0</td><td>7159\u00a0768\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Valid <em>g</em><sub>auto</sub>\u00a0</td><td>7114\u00a0967\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Match to WISE\u00a0</td><td>5156\u00a0101\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Match to VHS\u00a0</td><td>4344\u00a0994\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Valid <em>JKW</em>1<em>W</em>2\u00a0</td><td>4171\u00a0836\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GMM quasars\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0651\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>i</em><sub>psf</sub> \u2212 <em>i</em><sub>model</sub> &gt; 0.1\u00a0</td><td>7634\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Visual inspection (equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>)\u00a0</td><td>4778\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Criterion<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Objects remaining<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>DES Y1: <em>i</em><sub>auto</sub> &lt; 0.1\u00a0</td><td>7634\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Visual inspection (equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>)\u00a0</td><td>4778\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436949\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate selection.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Criterion<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Objects remaining<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>DES Y1: <em>i</em><sub>auto</sub> &lt; 19.0\u00a0</td><td>7159\u00a0768\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Valid <em>g</em><sub>auto</sub>\u00a0</td><td>7114\u00a0967\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Match to WISE\u00a0</td><td>5156\u00a0101\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Match to VHS\u00a0</td><td>4344\u00a0994\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Valid <em>JKW</em>1<em>W</em>2\u00a0</td><td>4171\u00a0836\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GMM quasars\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0651\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>i</em><sub>psf</sub> \u2212 <em>i</em><sub>model</sub> &gt; 0.1\u00a0</td><td>7634\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Visual inspection (equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>)\u00a0</td><td>4778\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Criterion<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Objects remaining<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>DES Y1: <em>i</em><sub>auto</sub> &lt; 19.0\u00a0</td><td>7159\u00a0768\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Valid <em>g</em><sub>auto</sub>\u00a0</td><td>7114\u00a0967\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Match to WISE\u00a0</td><td>5156\u00a0101\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Match to VHS\u00a0</td><td>4344\u00a0994\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Valid <em>JKW</em>1<em>W</em>2\u00a0</td><td>4171\u00a0836\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GMM quasars\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0651\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>i</em><sub>psf</sub> \u2212 <em>i</em><sub>model</sub> &gt; 0.1\u00a0</td><td>7634\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Visual inspection (equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>)\u00a0</td><td>4778\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436949\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Motivated by the morphologies displayed by the simulated <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> lenses, we selected for visual inspection objects that displayed the following morphological criteria: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\!\\left\\lbrace \\begin{array}{lr}0.2&lt;i_{\\mathrm{psf}} - i_{\\mathrm{model}}&lt;1.9; \\\\\r\n\\mathrm{ellipticity}&lt;0.3. \\end{array} \\right.\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>Colour composites made of DES <em>g, r</em>, and <em>i</em> bands were generated and VDES J2325\u22125229, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, stood out. The separation between the two blue sources is \u223c2.9 arcsec. Despite clearly having three main components, J2325\u22125229 is only deblended into a double source in the DES catalogue and appears as a single source in the VHS catalogue. That being the case, the north-most blue object, B, did not match to a VHS counterpart within 1.44 arcsec (0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{.}^{\\circ}$|</span>0004) and therefore was not in the test sample. This is the reason why J2325\u22125229 was not flagged as a pair. The candidate selection was solely based on the fact that the south-most component of the system, made of A+G, shows quasar colours and an extended morphology and visual inspection was vital. The photometry of this component is dominated by the red central object, as can be seen in the colour\u2013colour plots in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In those plots, the candidate tends to lie closer to the galaxy colour locus, which means that classical colour cuts such as those applied by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) would not have classified this object as one or multiple quasars. This shows the importance of not applying any sort of pruning to the input sample. The photometry for J2325\u22125229 is detailed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> we also show the photometry for component B, when available.</div>                        <a id=\"58436951\" scrollto-destination=\"58436951\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=IyzdrmyGoGxg3-DyYpPG0YytCF5xJ8QmlNxVDhdC3lkEyHjSA8tyqwjaYNnNzmFw1IF0iHvQOKUrTiRmjP16~IU0xARwTqjrMmUTgu5M6kdHhFzcjH25SSzI-M6ljn-TapL4LSKOmi81Xxei3de-BkuG-WOPuGfjNivkTbuZQgtGsnS8~5SwrbELFZIAon3DoEdnnCf-lI3~rhYbLlSLjG-5nc82c-n~p9wciMuFuDIxPebI9ZQyLNMiWLl6rCJHNFtiDAZG78p5kFdsesLJbDEVl7Hl1Tb2KDvcQS54FNlOcc05ZZJdBHo4RkToQlocLIwHhceaPR~Wj7E7Px4~~g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"J2325\u22125229 as a g, r, and i DES Y1 colour composite, an i-band image, an i-band image model and the residuals from subtracting the model from the image. North is up and East is left.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"58436952\" scrollto-destination=\"58436952\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=a4mdBTtAeMZahaOoThCVnPjOxPRWxN19FSXYST7vMRXNhtGJg334sc9jDsANe3v1cKp3I68aLCU3FiREfWvVRtWCNG5XLNtrWUOkZAa0YVJuTYYobzOOBdwFZ2e-9uGhoDAVwSgti-~6xbMBgKXCqDJR7~LGe1MWIby4oFA~so~2iJUqqtKRLGK0sSpfqbRmwVsndHm8POBiwbLH1MKYF-UExZWXqM0T4nle752JgGu7orZ7n0xlcINvWt1OVObtj3QDIJUj1RQuHTWxgN7tqDyMjNS6G9kkviJFyICwX5c0r-q2CPTbb-tbKNleUoyRRclk4d-LUdDHJwqcC5-P0w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour plots showing the location of J2325\u22125229 (pink circle) in different colour spaces. The pink square shows the location of the north-most blue object. We did not assign W1 flux to each counterpart, so values on the second diagram show, for both cases, the sum of all flux in that band. For comparison, the colour locus of quasars (green), point sources (blue) and extended sources (orange) are populated by the objects present in the GMM training set. The lensing galaxy dominates the colours of the system, making J2325\u22125229 an outlier of the quasar colour locus. In the left-most plot the stars represent each component of the system after 2D modelling for the photometry (quasar images are yellow and lensing galaxy is red). All magnitudes are in the AB system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436952/stw2958fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436952\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=IBcZhdb8BbLY1T1bmEKrEWKvPEJ3she3pjUj0g9DzvdT-nAPHU2DLmJ9i5oeWpbmFWLcvjj7R83Fgp-HWKz06TztujTXoPVB546Vu1~pe22FYFfwXjjrsdDHhOQ8mJ3BiNQ~VLnA1CQTAidWGbsgOXang4wyVxn--wD1DJWZCgw42WRnLiWnBuKTbyCIsmef58-1I5bJAT2xrQTKA5WnoAzp1oXmP~vaYM8fUSUnG5aaOZTYbgmQgjggcTd6SjITwlB1hWDqLDtTlpqcWPLMwlfSZDhMD2AStz0~wpI0JIvCO6F4FfHyC3Uvhpt7FXr3avtsuwmn5BUctz~WGGZXAA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436952&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour plots showing the location of J2325\u22125229 (pink circle) in different colour spaces. The pink square shows the location of the north-most blue object. We did not assign W1 flux to each counterpart, so values on the second diagram show, for both cases, the sum of all flux in that band. For comparison, the colour locus of quasars (green), point sources (blue) and extended sources (orange) are populated by the objects present in the GMM training set. The lensing galaxy dominates the colours of the system, making J2325\u22125229 an outlier of the quasar colour locus. In the left-most plot the stars represent each component of the system after 2D modelling for the photometry (quasar images are yellow and lensing galaxy is red). All magnitudes are in the AB system.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=a4mdBTtAeMZahaOoThCVnPjOxPRWxN19FSXYST7vMRXNhtGJg334sc9jDsANe3v1cKp3I68aLCU3FiREfWvVRtWCNG5XLNtrWUOkZAa0YVJuTYYobzOOBdwFZ2e-9uGhoDAVwSgti-~6xbMBgKXCqDJR7~LGe1MWIby4oFA~so~2iJUqqtKRLGK0sSpfqbRmwVsndHm8POBiwbLH1MKYF-UExZWXqM0T4nle752JgGu7orZ7n0xlcINvWt1OVObtj3QDIJUj1RQuHTWxgN7tqDyMjNS6G9kkviJFyICwX5c0r-q2CPTbb-tbKNleUoyRRclk4d-LUdDHJwqcC5-P0w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour plots showing the location of J2325\u22125229 (pink circle) in different colour spaces. The pink square shows the location of the north-most blue object. We did not assign W1 flux to each counterpart, so values on the second diagram show, for both cases, the sum of all flux in that band. For comparison, the colour locus of quasars (green), point sources (blue) and extended sources (orange) are populated by the objects present in the GMM training set. The lensing galaxy dominates the colours of the system, making J2325\u22125229 an outlier of the quasar colour locus. B</sub>\u00a0</td><td>18.14 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>19.95 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td><em>W</em>2<sub>A + G + B</sub>\u00a0</td><td>17.54 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>All quoted magnitudes are AB.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Magnitudes are auto for DES, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sqrt{2}$|</span> arcsec aperture for VHS and measured with profile-fitting photometry for WISE.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436953\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58436954 id=\"58436954\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 2D modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Once a lensed quasar candidate is selected from visual inspection, the next stage is to perform a 2D modelling of the system to ascertain what model the sources are most consistent with and to obtain photometry for each component. We modelled J2325\u22125229 in all five DES bands and in VHS <em>K</em> band. Image quality made the modelling in the <em>J</em> band unreliable and the resolution from WISE makes it impossible to resolve components with these separations. The positions of each component are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58436956\" scrollto-destination=\"58436956\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div modelled positions, photometry and photometric redshift.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n
