0.80\u00a0</td><td>1.23\u00a0</td><td>229.6\u00a0</td><td>20.75\u00a0</td><td>20.29\u00a0</td><td>20.24\u00a0</td><td>20.06\u00a0</td><td>20.05\u00a0</td><td>19.41\u00a0</td><td>2.920\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B\u00a0</td><td>23:25:41.25\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 52:29:13.5\u00a0</td><td>0.49\u00a0</td><td>1.72\u00a0</td><td>1.79\u00a0</td><td>15.9\u00a0</td><td>21.41\u00a0</td><td>20.99\u00a0</td><td>20.72\u00a0</td><td>20.57\u00a0</td><td>20.53\u00a0</td><td>19.71\u00a0</td><td>2.960\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A-B\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 1.43\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 2.52\u00a0</td><td>2.90\u00a0</td><td>29.6\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.66\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.70\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.48\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.51\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.48\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.30\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b1 (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b4 (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>R</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PA (\u00b0)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>g</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>i</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Y</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>K</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Photo-<em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>G\u00a0</td><td>23:25:41.20\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 52:29:15.1\u00a0</td><td>0.00\u00a0</td><td>0.00\u00a0</td><td>0.00\u00a0</td><td>00.0\u00a0</td><td>20.77\u00a0</td><td>18.88\u00a0</td><td>18.50\u00a0</td><td>18.14\u00a0</td><td>17.95\u00a0</td><td>17.15\u00a0</td><td>0.302\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A\u00a0</td><td>23:25:41.10\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 52:29:15.9\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.94\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.80\u00a0</td><td>1.23\u00a0</td><td>229.6\u00a0</td><td>20.75\u00a0</td><td>20.29\u00a0</td><td>20.24\u00a0</td><td>20.06\u00a0</td><td>20.05\u00a0</td><td>19.41\u00a0</td><td>2.920\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B\u00a0</td><td>23:25:41.25\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 52:29:13.5\u00a0</td><td>0.49\u00a0</td><td>1.72\u00a0</td><td>1.79\u00a0</td><td>15.9\u00a0</td><td>21.41\u00a0</td><td>20.99\u00a0</td><td>20.72\u00a0</td><td>20.57\u00a0</td><td>20.53\u00a0</td><td>19.71\u00a0</td><td>2.960\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A-B\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 1.43\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 2.52\u00a0</td><td>2.90\u00a0</td><td>29.6\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.66\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.70\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.48\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.51\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.48\u00a0</td><td>\u2212 0.30\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436956\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The modelling, analogous to what was done by Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), used <span class=\"small-caps\">Python</span> routines to combine two Moffat profile PSFs plus a S\u00e9rsic profile galaxy convolved with the PSF for the system's image. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> the <em>i</em>-band image, the model image and the residual signal obtained from subtracting the two images are displayed. The ellipticity of the lensing galaxy, according to the best model, is <em>q</em> = 0.19 \u00b1 0.03 with a position angle of 70\u00b0 \u00b1 5\u00b0. The S\u00e9rsic index is 3.9 \u00b1 0.4.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each component, the modelled photometry is listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and from those values it is possible to plot spectral energy distributions (SED) for each component, which can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. As was evident from the colours of the A+G blended component, the lensing galaxy is brighter than the quasar images. The difference is of approximately 1 mag in the bluer bands and it can reach almost 3 mag in the redder bands.</p>                        <a id=\"58436959\" scrollto-destination=\"58436959\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=en0T4e7ZtTIL07oj62kioZl1M19znGxvggFYc3WL1zIGsRZ46i3wwvxREXv8u3wXZlZJCeneFYt2~~fMzSvnJhl4P~G07-MM33W6lAqcEYEJr8u4eJGfHYUqGNl~iPUF7suCSZPAFaVtFeUZfUrwaqFppQX1hb6apdVNu0kb~0A9sAeM1tYN8KySleAOemP9AQOdL6lpMl4g~lmPpdSH1Q6yU-4yM2MFQA-0lPEl4Z059MgnLA9~JHH8j0CT0fgkNmrEzZsvwNtr84dQV8Kbr8coUtphV5gaU5Rp5mGB6ZSHBoXeW-0bKbKK3lwgwdVrDRhsQLuxygsmeKi6S2QysQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SEDs of the three components of the J2325\u22125229 system after modelling the photometry. The continuous lines show the best-fitting SED template fitted by LePHARE.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436959/stw2958fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436959\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=dWR8qbzTgBBm-r7fQmLYbw3uawOAiliTsp1mjITAXBjq-DpAihH2E9xjS1kuJkvIUGQJSTbCPxFS60xzZz~0yc~fMeorwpZp-bKJLu~DMv0Q8pSWhZ9v1yZvCRA2W~0pdl01pPUhR9c5yz~4wiI5YjkPmNXcA3RGwV~Rxy5nZ2AFIuswXx1eArEWoc9Y3yGF6gvVoQoRNodhsmsrnKn-y6dADo2TSjJMwLdnMEXkFdwFe0CQhav7YDARrwCMAzVjFvVpoNRPm2-vHCNP~D7crX~a60EOaiapduJ9Rt0G8p3aRGLkqfWDc2ZiDLJbjiq~A-~JBZwqw4hetPLvGBcqhA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436959&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SEDs of the three components of the J2325\u22125229 system after modelling the photometry. The continuous lines show the best-fitting SED template fitted by LePHARE.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=en0T4e7ZtTIL07oj62kioZl1M19znGxvggFYc3WL1zIGsRZ46i3wwvxREXv8u3wXZlZJCeneFYt2~~fMzSvnJhl4P~G07-MM33W6lAqcEYEJr8u4eJGfHYUqGNl~iPUF7suCSZPAFaVtFeUZfUrwaqFppQX1hb6apdVNu0kb~0A9sAeM1tYN8KySleAOemP9AQOdL6lpMl4g~lmPpdSH1Q6yU-4yM2MFQA-0lPEl4Z059MgnLA9~JHH8j0CT0fgkNmrEzZsvwNtr84dQV8Kbr8coUtphV5gaU5Rp5mGB6ZSHBoXeW-0bKbKK3lwgwdVrDRhsQLuxygsmeKi6S2QysQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SEDs of the three components of the J2325\u22125229 system after modelling the photometry. The continuous lines show the best-fitting SED template fitted by LePHARE.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436959/stw2958fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436959\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=dWR8qbzTgBBm-r7fQmLYbw3uawOAiliTsp1mjITAXBjq-DpAihH2E9xjS1kuJkvIUGQJSTbCPxFS60xzZz~0yc~fMeorwpZp-bKJLu~DMv0Q8pSWhZ9v1yZvCRA2W~0pdl01pPUhR9c5yz~4wiI5YjkPmNXcA3RGwV~Rxy5nZ2AFIuswXx1eArEWoc9Y3yGF6gvVoQoRNodhsmsrnKn-y6dADo2TSjJMwLdnMEXkFdwFe0CQhav7YDARrwCMAzVjFvVpoNRPm2-vHCNP~D7crX~a60EOaiapduJ9Rt0G8p3aRGLkqfWDc2ZiDLJbjiq~A-~JBZwqw4hetPLvGBcqhA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436959&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SEDs of the three components of the J2325\u22125229 system after modelling the photometry. The continuous lines show the best-fitting SED template fitted by LePHARE.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The modelled colours, displayed on the <em>gri</em> colour\u2013colour diagram in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, show that the two blue components are indeed consistent with the quasar locus. The difference between the colours of the quasar-like components can be explained by contamination from the galaxy-like component on the bright counterpart that is projected closer to it. That is supported by the fact that the biggest colour difference is seen in <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em>, where the galaxy is brighter, and not in <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em>. It is also clear, by comparing the modelled photometry of B to that available in the DES catalogue, that despite being segmented, it still contains part of the lensing galaxy flux, particularly in the red bands.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The modelled photometry enables us to calculate photometric redshifts (photo-<em>z</em>) for each component. This was done using the SED fitting code LePHARE (Arnouts et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Ilbert et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The method compares, through \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization, the observed magnitudes of a given object with those predicted by the SED which has been convolved with the filter transmission curves. Reddening, interstellar extinction and the opacity of the intergalactic medium are taken into account.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We used two sets of SED libraries made available with the code: one for galaxy fitting and one for quasars. The first is composed of four observed spectra from Coleman, Wu &amp; Weedman (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) (linearly extrapolated into ultraviolet and near-IR wavelengths) representing elliptical, irregular, Sbc and Scd galaxies, plus six observed starburst SEDs from the Kinney atlas described in Calzetti, Kinney &amp; Storchi-Bergmann (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>). The second library is composed of seven synthetic quasar spectra with varying equivalent widths for the Lyman \u03b1 and N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> lines and both with and without contribution from a blackbody (<em>T</em> = 24\u00a0000\u00a0K) component. A power-law component with spectral indexes of \u03b1 = \u22121.0 for 597 &lt; \u03bb &lt; 10\u2009000\u2009\u00c5 and \u03b1 = \u22120.7 for 10\u2009000 &lt; \u03bb &lt; 25\u2009000\u2009\u00c5 was used on all quasar spectra.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the photometric errors, we estimated 0.1 in each band as an approximation. The best-fitting photo-<em>z</em> results for each component are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The lensing galaxy was best fitted with an elliptical template. Synthetic spectra with different equivalent widths for spectral lines were used to best fit each quasar image, which is not surprising, given that object A is likely to be more heavily contaminated by the lensing galaxy light. The best-fitting templates are over-plotted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> for each component.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58436964 id=\"58436964\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 SPECTROSCOPIC OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58436965 id=\"58436965\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 NTT</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations were carried out with the ESO Faint Object Spectrograph and Camera 2 (EFOSC2; Buzzoni et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>) mounted at the f/11 nasmyth focus on the 3.6-m NTT on the night of 2015 October 7/8th <span class=\"small-caps\">ut</span> as part of ESO observing programme 096-A-041. The 236 lines/mm Grism 13 blazed at 4400\u00a0\u00c5 was used giving a 5.54\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> (binned 2\u00d72) and a spectral resolution of 23.0\u00a0\u00c5 for 1 arcsec seeing (FWHM). The full spectral coverage was 3700\u20139315\u00a0\u00c5 with a delivered spectral resolution (FWHM) of 34.5\u00a0\u00c5 (6\u00a0pixels) and 1.5 arcsec seeing during the observations. The spectroscopic slit was aligned with PA = 214\u00b0 so that both candidate quasar components were centred in the slit. No order blocking filter (e.g. GG475) was used since the largest wavelength range was required for redshift determination and hence there will be some second-order contamination at wavelengths longer than 2 \u00d7 3700\u00a0\u00c5 = 7400\u00a0\u00c5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The 2D data were reduced following the guidelines of the PESSTO project (Smartt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) using a set of custom <span class=\"small-caps\">Python</span> routines with bias frames and flat-fields taken during the afternoon prior to the observations. 1D spectra were extracted centred on the two quasar locations with wavelength calibration applied using Arc lamp observations that were taken immediately after the spectroscopic observations of the science target. The separation of the two quasars is 2.9 arcsec with the galaxy lying between the two quasars and separated 1.2 arcsec from the brighter quasar component A and 1.7 arcsec from component B. Therefore, the galaxy contributes to the spectra of both quasars and is unresolved with respect to quasar component A in the seeing of 1.5 arcsec. The resultant 1D extracted spectra are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58436968\" scrollto-destination=\"58436968\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=gvDNqziguineY5SsIUI0notkaFY3oc~tCTOJ~Po59kmAhLR1nEN7m0hYC636fcyYCRnBA2Mhu8DcEvLRyGGi2YPlyxTuo5noj92PHsUcmntLa4FlcAu37Srs-EKNbE-CMYKUKNEaFip31jg8kWoKZTqUDaYPessVB4AAjXqpmxRx3q6W9pCeOsLewEv-gc4sdad9L7Y~PYw6KP6-ebTQOmPquw3Q2IDT~LSD9F0LPbfyk9HSoirxuF~Mr8dY2FFy-ti1znNqUqZ6pj8eopK7ozGhCIVKRyOtxsCPlN2H4Q2Wm9JAKkm9wGzO0dhKZyztlfWOa51D1rcklq9mdnH9sA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"1D NTT spectra. The top (green) spectrum is the brighter component A and the lower (yellow) spectrum is component B. On top, we have marked the location of the source quasar emission lines at zem = 2.739 (solid lines) and absorption lines at zab = 2.705 (dashed lines). On the bottom are the lensing galaxy absorption lines at zab = 0.401. In blue, we show A\u2013B after scaling the flux of image B by the median flux ratio between the two quasars bluewards of 4000\u2009\u00c5.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436968/stw2958fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436968\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=vWTSWmlgR2-pwloEczzS2pQ5WlyRq9YFzeJbmwGl8QThw7I4e7HA3nJWpyrfzJemXC8DrDu1J6Nw6mPUcCrcRBoIUxcOBhKTZebReXvw3mqPEcgDAcWYOxz-p9aqUeqpMSciqFivsExTAJ-qpjDV1lz7Ijv-8BdndvsJZxfBtk6e2H1pUrAoncLXXPuSwS~zRagCeVeO2WsQVZePSTkQsvAecMIjsfYS0HbIYe62M1FKjgITwPAULyDGbbrCawUOYCnQU-nvSSwxYTl-pJ3KvPmFKVe1r5uN-KSDAQB24JrFyjGtoQ3wMjLasKxI7FyV~po7NgE5roMW0LDwwyQFUw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436968&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">1D NTT spectra. The top (green) spectrum is the brighter component A and the lower (yellow) spectrum is component B. On top, we have marked the location of the source quasar emission lines at <em>z</em><sub>em</sub> = 2.739 (solid lines) and absorption lines at <em>z</em><sub>ab</sub> = 2.705 (dashed lines). On the bottom are the lensing galaxy absorption lines at <em>z</em><sub>ab</sub> = 0.401. In blue, we show A\u2013B after scaling the flux of image B by the median flux ratio between the two quasars bluewards of 4000\u2009\u00c5.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=gvDNqziguineY5SsIUI0notkaFY3oc~tCTOJ~Po59kmAhLR1nEN7m0hYC636fcyYCRnBA2Mhu8DcEvLRyGGi2YPlyxTuo5noj92PHsUcmntLa4FlcAu37Srs-EKNbE-CMYKUKNEaFip31jg8kWoKZTqUDaYPessVB4AAjXqpmxRx3q6W9pCeOsLewEv-gc4sdad9L7Y~PYw6KP6-ebTQOmPquw3Q2IDT~LSD9F0LPbfyk9HSoirxuF~Mr8dY2FFy-ti1znNqUqZ6pj8eopK7ozGhCIVKRyOtxsCPlN2H4Q2Wm9JAKkm9wGzO0dhKZyztlfWOa51D1rcklq9mdnH9sA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"1D NTT spectra. The top (green) spectrum is the brighter component A and the lower (yellow) spectrum is component B. On top, we have marked the location of the source quasar emission lines at zem = 2.739 (solid lines) and absorption lines at zab = 2.705 (dashed lines). On the bottom are the lensing galaxy absorption lines at zab = 0.401. In blue, we show A\u2013B after scaling the flux of image B by the median flux ratio between the two quasars bluewards of 4000\u2009\u00c5.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436968/stw2958fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436968\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=vWTSWmlgR2-pwloEczzS2pQ5WlyRq9YFzeJbmwGl8QThw7I4e7HA3nJWpyrfzJemXC8DrDu1J6Nw6mPUcCrcRBoIUxcOBhKTZebReXvw3mqPEcgDAcWYOxz-p9aqUeqpMSciqFivsExTAJ-qpjDV1lz7Ijv-8BdndvsJZxfBtk6e2H1pUrAoncLXXPuSwS~zRagCeVeO2WsQVZePSTkQsvAecMIjsfYS0HbIYe62M1FKjgITwPAULyDGbbrCawUOYCnQU-nvSSwxYTl-pJ3KvPmFKVe1r5uN-KSDAQB24JrFyjGtoQ3wMjLasKxI7FyV~po7NgE5roMW0LDwwyQFUw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436968&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">1D NTT spectra. The top (green) spectrum is the brighter component A and the lower (yellow) spectrum is component B. On top, we have marked the location of the source quasar emission lines at <em>z</em><sub>em</sub> = 2.739 (solid lines) and absorption lines at <em>z</em><sub>ab</sub> = 2.705 (dashed lines). On the bottom are the lensing galaxy absorption lines at <em>z</em><sub>ab</sub> = 0.401. In blue, we show A\u2013B after scaling the flux of image B by the median flux ratio between the two quasars bluewards of 4000\u2009\u00c5.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58436969 id=\"58436969\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 AAT archival data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A search for J2325\u22125229 in other data archives showed it was part of the XXL survey that used the <em>XMM\u2013Newton</em> X-ray telescope to image 50\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in two fields between 2011 and 2013 (Pierre et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The total X-ray flux for the source is 3.70 \u00b1 1.10 \u00d7 10<sup>\u221214</sup>erg cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The Anglo-Australian Telescope (AAT) was one of the facilities to provide spectroscopic follow-up for the southern XXL field. The follow-up is detailed in Lidman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), where they describe the use of the two-degree field (2dF) fibre positioner in conjunction with the AAOmega spectrograph with a spectral coverage of 3700\u20138900\u2009\u00c5 and spectral resolution of about 1500 or 4\u00a0\u00c5 at 6000\u00a0\u00c5. The data processing is also described.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Data for J2325\u22125229 were obtained between 2013 September 08 and 09 and the 1D spectrum can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The data were processed with 2dfdr<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> through the Australian Dark Energy Survey (OzDES) pipeline (Yuan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Because the fibre diameter on the sky is \u223c2 arcsec and the separation between the quasar images is \u223c2.9 arcsec, most of the flux arises from the lensing galaxy, and the galaxy spectral features are much more prominent in this spectrum than in the NTT spectra. For this reason, the object was not flagged as an AGN in the AAT catalogue. There is, however, clear evidence for quasar features, Lyman \u03b1 in particular at \u03bb \u223c 4600\u00a0\u00c5.</p>                        <a id=\"58436972\" scrollto-destination=\"58436972\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=TprFgwFm00eO10o1b5qr6KPdrhb5VRN4wSzCdGGcRN0tgS0lr5zo-GmE~vBnlSS30bvrpLTV0lHIR3tTQjv9lWftwim~ZW5i7ipqEw18Av49TorhhqTX9VfVa6Dje~jk1yeOo0nAzGseq-oO86xXfaD731Xb2XfKXlRO6ElKBOoj1AVPn824rPF~iAVFtH9QTshY~h8QasA-~Rq-dKIyiArM3qwE09qbSKNxhZ5uf3z-18tZkQEMPiONec0myfWIW-yCwhPV4WSCpJ6wBKbBreUjKpITBqvkpbvCP4goBr3DN5b-7xeABMJKpQW6t738uhaKJOPbaHN2UfmfqJ688g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"1D AAT spectrum from archival data. The dashed lines show the location of typical galaxy absorption lines at the given AAT z = 0.399 redshift.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436972/stw2958fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436972\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=TUW5X4MObp68Zgottp-UOWiIHOlxNrakDYH7DoXQwfycmnruLIOVv0m~X-bzhC52KcVw3WKRLHdv4F7sWYjowHZ4c7mxjyrVRXi13187agCTSwAyoAeYZbz015ogvRIKH-nFKQuDkhFeJQ~A6LT5o217aGWokry2FJfO2a2VbSCufesxHk7tTXYNKO9v82-rsok3fOY~Kx8phXpaSPr6nJ7aO60qGaquT3DV8f75C-QHgbB-EOYuAPyRXT-oybFSlTlxTKC1G2o0IZSEa6c-AaUEKyBGyBo6z8j0dPM38OSvWsgXld2vRmx99IY4e3TcB~6VwnVnFGFyFYBy4RJpXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436972&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">1D AAT spectrum from archival data. The dashed lines show the location of typical galaxy absorption lines at the given AAT <em>z</em> = 0.399 redshift.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=TprFgwFm00eO10o1b5qr6KPdrhb5VRN4wSzCdGGcRN0tgS0lr5zo-GmE~vBnlSS30bvrpLTV0lHIR3tTQjv9lWftwim~ZW5i7ipqEw18Av49TorhhqTX9VfVa6Dje~jk1yeOo0nAzGseq-oO86xXfaD731Xb2XfKXlRO6ElKBOoj1AVPn824rPF~iAVFtH9QTshY~h8QasA-~Rq-dKIyiArM3qwE09qbSKNxhZ5uf3z-18tZkQEMPiONec0myfWIW-yCwhPV4WSCpJ6wBKbBreUjKpITBqvkpbvCP4goBr3DN5b-7xeABMJKpQW6t738uhaKJOPbaHN2UfmfqJ688g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"1D AAT spectrum from archival data. The dashed lines show the location of typical galaxy absorption lines at the given AAT z = 0.399 redshift.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58436972/stw2958fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58436972\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/stw2958fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&Signature=TUW5X4MObp68Zgottp-UOWiIHOlxNrakDYH7DoXQwfycmnruLIOVv0m~X-bzhC52KcVw3WKRLHdv4F7sWYjowHZ4c7mxjyrVRXi13187agCTSwAyoAeYZbz015ogvRIKH-nFKQuDkhFeJQ~A6LT5o217aGWokry2FJfO2a2VbSCufesxHk7tTXYNKO9v82-rsok3fOY~Kx8phXpaSPr6nJ7aO60qGaquT3DV8f75C-QHgbB-EOYuAPyRXT-oybFSlTlxTKC1G2o0IZSEa6c-AaUEKyBGyBo6z8j0dPM38OSvWsgXld2vRmx99IY4e3TcB~6VwnVnFGFyFYBy4RJpXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58436972&ar=2544365&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw2958fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">1D AAT spectrum from archival data. The dashed lines show the location of typical galaxy absorption lines at the given AAT <em>z</em> = 0.399 redshift.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58436973 id=\"58436973\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Redshift determination</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We measured the wavelength of prominent emission and absorption features in the NTT spectra using the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> (v2.16; Tody\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>) <span class=\"small-caps\">splot</span> software. The peak or minimum and centroids were measured for each feature. The two measurements generally agreed to within 5\u00a0\u00c5 which is consistent with the spectral resolution (FWHM) of 35\u00a0\u00c5 i.e. 0.2\u00a0pixels. Throughout, unless specified, we use rest-frame laboratory wavelengths from Morton (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>) and Tytler &amp; Fan (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Both spectra show evidence of a strong emission feature at \u223c4540\u00a0\u00c5 which we initially identified as redshifted hydrogen Lyman \u03b1 (\u03bb<sub>rest</sub> = 1215.7\u2009\u00c5) at an emission line redshift of <em>z</em> = 2.73. At this redshift, one expects to see broad N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> (1240.1\u00a0\u00c5) C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> (1549.1\u00a0\u00c5) and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] (1908.7\u00a0\u00c5) within the observed spectral window at 4631\u2009\u00c5, 5778\u00a0\u00c5 and 7119\u00a0\u00c5 respectively. Both spectra have potential lines at these wavelengths. In addition, there is evidence of absorption lines blueward of the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> permitted lines. No absorption is expected for C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] since this is a semi-forbidden transition. The observed wavelengths of these features are tabulated in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> for each spectrum. We also calculate average emission line and absorption line redshifts excluding the tentative C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] line. We determine emission line redshifts of 2.739 \u00b1 0.003 for component A and 2.732 for component B. The absorption line redshifts are 2.705 \u00b1 0.001 for component A and 2.698 \u00b1 0.004 for component B, corresponding to a blueshift with respect to the emission line redshifts of 0.034 or 2700\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> which is within the range of associated absorption seen in many quasars including mini-BALs. The study of the absorption line velocity and intensity profiles in two sightlines can be used to probe the out-flowing winds of quasars (e.g. Misawa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"58436976\" scrollto-destination=\"58436976\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" (?): identification uncertain.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>Rest frame laboratory wavelengths from Tytler &amp; Fan (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] was not used to calculate average redshifts.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436976\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the photometric redshift of 0.302 from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a>, we expect the Calcium K and H to have observed wavelengths of 5121.68\u00a0\u00c5 and 5166.99\u00a0\u00c5, respectively. In order to make the galaxy absorption lines more evident in the NTT spectra, we tried to remove the quasar contribution by subtracting the two spectra. But first, we scaled the flux of the fainter image by using the median flux ratio between the two quasars blueward of 4000\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0where the galaxy contamination would be negligible. The subtracted spectrum is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. There is evidence of a doublet at \u223c5530\u00a0\u00c5 in both spectra and we identify this as calcium H and K. We also identify absorption lines consistent with Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and NaD. The average redshift derived from these lines is 0.401 \u00b1 0.001. We make similar measurements from the AAT spectrum and derive a redshift of 0.400 \u00b1 0.003 as can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58436978\" scrollto-destination=\"58436978\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" 0.003$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN006\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN006\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> (?): identification uncertain.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN007\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN007\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combined average redshift: 0.400 \u00b1 0.002.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436978\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Subsequent to our measurements of the AAT spectrum, Lidman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) published their independent analysis of these data and report a redshift of 0.3996 \u00b1 0.0003. We take the redshift to be the average of our NTT and AAT analysis at 0.400 \u00b1 0.002 which is consistent within 0.0004 with the Lidman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) determination.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58436980 id=\"58436980\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to the low number of constraints in a double image system, we can only investigate simple lens models, in particular the singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE).We model the lens system using the public lensing software, <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). There are eight constraints from observations (positions of the two quasar images and their fluxes, and the position of the lensing galaxy) and eight model parameters (position and flux of the source quasar, position of the lensing galaxy, its mass, ellipticity and position angle). Hence, the model has zero degrees of freedom and we expect solutions to converge to \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u223c 0. To estimate uncertainties on the model parameters, we generated 2000 data sets from the constraints and their errors (as in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), including a deviation in the mass density power law of an SIE of 0.1, which covers the observed density distribution in early-type galaxies (Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We use the <em>i</em>-band magnitudes as image fluxes and increase the uncertainty on the fluxes by 0.1\u00a0mag because of possible contaminations, such as microlensing, dust extinction and intrinsic quasar variability over the time delay (e.g. Hook et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> we show the diagrams of critical lines and caustics in both the image and the source planes, obtained using GRAVLENS (Keeton\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). The results are in agreement with the <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> model. The source quasar is close to the inner caustic but not inside it, which is the reason why the quasar is only doubly lensed. Summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> are the modelling results for Einstein radius (<em>R</em><sub>E</sub>), ellipticity (<em>q</em>), position angle, time delay (\u0394<em>t</em>), enclosed mass (<em>M</em><sub>enclosed</sub>) and magnification (\u03bc). Images A and B are magnified by \u22126.5 \u00b1 2.2 and 3.8 \u00b1 1.0, respectively, where the negative sign denotes a parity flip. The time delay was found to be \u0394<em>t</em> = 52 \u00b1 11\u00a0d (A follows B), given a Hubble constant <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 68 kms<sup>\u22121</sup>Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. The discrepancy between position angles measured through the light profile (2D modelling) and mass modelling seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> is possibly due to the unknown external shear (Keeton, Kochanek &amp; Falco\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"58436983\" scrollto-destination=\"58436983\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw2958/1/m_stw2958fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466690&amp;Signature=NolW5vNevy-hju8F3Hh-cym3oWTSFVTIZ4yHrs9-mKNRlNotQmMMuin-75AgJeutHN6SWXU1h5S0druqI5skw7XHgtcjyTm6JFWltxAROmvg7iRRT33LnO1Et4TswQ3Btpr68n-QHe1D8eFUXyX1G3zWqa9IQ9Ic3nCPLubCPFSJiDAlhu7aZCh1gkvNTjE9m4f8MDhTeUJ0r-vZCosA8cX-rI1rI3tZCiHoAnFvvhI2dU~pXgfKKSPh-ia7HK6V2SN-ZKIza-8FOC5O4o0ieNJHYdhlt1LvJn3BFbfZ98CpPOQYKc71EeA~CYoe~0BLtPytV7OZuuWIQhr8myXAtg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Caustics and critical lines obtained after the mass distribution modelling of J2325. \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>PA\u00a0</td><td>97\u00b0 \u00b1 4\u00b0\u00a0</td><td>70\u00b0 \u00b1 5\u00b0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u0394<em>t</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>52 \u00b1 .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>R</em><sub>E</sub>\u00a0</td><td>1.47\u2033 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>q\u00a0</td><td>0.23 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.19 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>PA\u00a0</td><td>97\u00b0 \u00b1 4\u00b0\u00a0</td><td>70\u00b0 \u00b1 5\u00b0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u0394<em>t</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>52 \u00b1 class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436984\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Parameters of J2325\u22125229.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.19 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>PA\u00a0</td><td>97\u00b0 \u00b1 4\u00b0\u00a0</td><td>70\u00b0 \u00b1 5\u00b0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u0394<em>t</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>52 \u00b1 11\u00a0d\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>enclosed</sub>\u00a0</td><td>(4.04 \u00b1 0.15) \u00d7 10<sup>11</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03bc\u00a0</td><td>10 \u00b1 3\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Lens model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>2D model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>R</em><sub>E</sub>\u00a0</td><td>1.47\u2033 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>q\u00a0</td><td>0.23 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.19 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>PA\u00a0</td><td>97\u00b0 \u00b1 4\u00b0\u00a0</td><td>70\u00b0 \u00b1 5\u00b0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u0394<em>t</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>52 \u00b1 11\u00a0d\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>enclosed</sub>\u00a0</td><td>(4.04 \u00b1 0.15) \u00d7 10<sup>11</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03bc\u00a0</td><td>10 \u00b1 3\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN008\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN008\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup> Time delays are positive if A follows B.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/58436984\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58436985 id=\"58436985\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have identified a high-redshift lensed quasar, VDES J2325\u22125229, by applying GMM supervised machine learning to select the candidates in a colour space defined by DES+VHS+WISE photometric bands. Since the selection does not depend on the <em>u</em> band, we are capable of selecting candidates at higher redshifts. For comparison, amongst the 49 new lenses found by SQLS, only six have source redshifts greater than J2325, three of which were serendipitously discovered (Johnston et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Pindor et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; McGreer et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Two more lenses with source redshifts greater than J2325 were discovered in SDSS-III BOSS quasar lens survey (More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), including the highest redshift multiply lensed quasar known, with <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.819.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the geometry of the system, with the presence of an obvious LRG galaxy, and an angular separation between the quasars that converts to a physical distance of \u223c23.2\u2009kpc, it is unlikely that we are looking at distinct binary quasars. The quasar SEDs are considerably similar, with emission line redshifts that differ by 562 \u00b1 240\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in the quasar rest frame. Given the poor seeing during the NTT spectroscopic observations and the contamination from the lensing galaxy particularly in the SED of quasar component A, that discrepancy is not surprising. Both quasar images present an intrinsic absorption line system detected in C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> and N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>, blueshifted by 2739 \u00b1 254\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in component A and 2744 \u00b1 324\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in component B with respect to the emission line redshift, further evidencing the SED similarity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There is evidence that the C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> absorption line is weaker in image B, which would be consistent with different sightlines in the broad-line region of the source quasar as predicted by Misawa et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, where we have scaled the flux of image B by the median flux ratio between the two quasars blueward of 4000\u2009\u00c5, where the contamination of the lensing galaxy is most negligible, and subtracted B from A. A strong absorption feature remains at \u03bb \u223c 5734\u2009\u00c5, where the C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> absorption is expected to be for <em>z</em><sub>ab</sub> = 2.7. A lesser effect is seen at \u03bb \u223c 4596\u2009\u00c5, where one expects the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> absorption to be. This is unsurprising giving the ionization potentials of 64.5 and 97.9\u00a0eV for C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> and N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>, respectively, which means that N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> absorbers would be closer to the flux source, and therefore be less likely to be affected by differences in sightlines. Further high-resolution spectroscopy of J2325 would allow for the different sightlines scenario to be confirmed and to constrain the size of the absorber and geometry of the broad-emission line region.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The modelled <em>i</em>-band magnitude of the lensing galaxy can be used to estimate the rest-frame <em>R</em>-band magnitude. At these redshifts, and given our choice of rest and observed frame filters, the <em>K</em>-corrections can be neglected. For the LRG in J2325\u22125229, we calculate <em>M<sub>R</sub></em> = \u221222.41, given <em>z</em> = 0.4 and <em>m<sub>i</sub></em> = 18.50. We can compare this magnitude to that obtained by using the separation of the quasar images and the lensing Faber\u2013Jackson relation with fit parameters described in Rusin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) following what was done in Jackson, Ofek &amp; Oguri (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Assuming <em>z</em> = 0.400 \u00b1 0.002 and \u03b8 = 2.90, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nM_{R}=M_{\\star R}+2.5\\gamma _{{\\rm E}+K}z-1.25\\gamma _{FJ}\\log {\\theta }\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>yields <em>M<sub>R</sub></em> = \u221223.11 \u00b1 0.53, which is close to the expected value obtained from modelling the data.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The next DES data release will contain data from the full 5000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> survey area and will provide a rich sample in which to look for lensed quasars. With such a large area, one can expect to find dozens of bright lenses, including those with quadruple images and the technique introduced in this paper should be able to select all of them as candidates.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58436991 id=\"58436991\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgments</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">FO is supported jointly by CAPES (the Science without Borders programme) and the Cambridge Commonwealth Trust.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">RGM, CAL, MWA, MB, SLR acknowledge the support of UK Science and Technology Research Jos\u00e9 Cristino 77, Rio de Janeiro, RJ - 20921-400, Brazil; ICTP South American Institute for Fundamental Research Instituto de F\u00edsica Te\u00f3rica, Universidade Estadual Paulista, S\u00e3o Paulo, Brazil), CC(Computer Science and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, USA), CD(Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA), CE(Institute of Cosmology &amp; Gravitation, University of Portsmouth, Portsmouth PO1 3FX, UK), CF(Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, PO Box 500, Batavia, IL 60510, USA), CG(Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory, National Optical Astronomy Observatory, Casilla 603, La Serena, Chile)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "465", "publication_year": "2017/03/1", "start_page": "4325", "end_page": "4334", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: observational", "methods: statistical", "quasars: general", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017MNRAS.465.4325O", "abstract": "We present the discovery and preliminary characterization of a gravitationally lensed quasar with a source redshift z<SUB>s</SUB> = 2.74 and image separation of 2.9 arcsec lensed by a foreground z<SUB>l</SUB> = 0.40 elliptical galaxy. Since optical observations of gravitationally lensed quasars show the lens system as a superposition of multiple point sources and a foreground lensing galaxy, we have developed a morphology-independent multi-wavelength approach to the photometric selection of lensed quasar candidates based on Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) supervised machine learning. Using this technique and gi multicolour photometric observations from the Dark Energy Survey (DES), near-IR JK photometry from the VISTA Hemisphere Survey (VHS) and WISE mid-IR photometry, we have identified a candidate system with two catalogue components with I<SUB>AB</SUB> = 18.61 and I<SUB>AB</SUB> = 20.44 comprising an elliptical galaxy and two blue point sources. Spectroscopic follow-up with NTT and the use of an archival AAT spectrum show that the point sources can be identified as a lensed quasar with an emission line redshift of z = 2.739 \u00b1 0.003 and a foreground early-type galaxy with z = 0.400 \u00b1 0.002. We model the system as a single isothermal ellipsoid and find the Einstein radius \u03b8<SUB>E</SUB> \u223c 1.47 arcsec, enclosed mass M<SUB>enc</SUB> \u223c 4 \u00d7 10<SUP>11</SUP> M<SUB>\u2609</SUB> and a time delay of \u223c52 d. The relatively wide separation, month scale time delay duration and high redshift make this an ideal system for constraining the expansion rate beyond a redshift of 1.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stw2958", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1607.01391", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
